title-group.article-title: Lifetime Generational Accounts for the Netherlands

abstract.p: Conventional generational accounting only includes future benefits and burdens from the government. This paper's contribution is to include past benefits and burdens as well, and in this way to provide a full lifetime account of how much current and future generations benefit from government, in net terms, under various future policy lines. The calculations are carried out for the Netherlands and for the cohorts born since 1946. The more complete picture may be helpful for political decision-making on equitable intergenerational policies. A second contribution of this paper is that it uses a more comprehensive benefit concept than other such backward-looking studies by including non-cash benefits as well. The results point out that there are substantial differences in net lifetime benefits between generations and these are mainly driven by non-cash benefits such as education and healthcare, on which expenditure increased substantially after 1946.

We impute the real discount rate in order to preserve the zero-sum property for government policies, which is a common feature of GA studies and enables us to focus on the redistribution aspect. For the same reason, we assume that the benefits from government expenditure equal its monetary cost.

Non-tax revenues consist of revenues from natural resources (mainly gas), presented separately in Table 1, and revenues from government financial assets, government sales and subsidies from the EU. In the period 1948-51, they also include the Marshall aid, a US aid programme to rebuild the European economies, which explains the high figure for 1950. The revenues from natural resources fluctuate due to changes in the volume and price of sales. After 1951, the other non-tax revenues fluctuate mainly as a result of fluctuations of holdings in and returns on financial assets. In Table 1, non-tax revenues are not added to taxes but are subtracted from total expenditure. This conforms with the way public finances are generally presented by CPB. This item, largely consisting of government sales, can be seen as a counter item of direct government expenditure and serves as a correction for the benefits from expenditure. Adding it to revenues might give a false and overstated notion of the tax burden.
The peak in both the deficit and net benefits in 1995 is the result of a one-off redemption by the government of future annual subsidies to housing corporations.

These age profiles are derived from various sources. The profile for healthcare consists of the profiles for cure and care, which are both based on information provided by RIVM (2007). The age profiles for the disability benefits are based on Van Sonsbeek and Alblas (2010), as is the future use of this government programme. The profile for public pensions is based on their institutional arrangement. Public pensions are granted to individuals from the age of 65. Being a flat-rate system other than granting a higher benefit to single people than to married individuals, the average benefit is imputed to rise slightly with age due to an increasing share of single households. The profiles for unemployment benefits and social assistance are assumed flat between the ages of 20 and 64 due to lack of information.

Only the shape of the profile remains unchanged. Its absolute size was adjusted in each year in order to equal the correct aggregate of the expenditure or revenue item.

The imputed age-specific changes in labour participation are based on Euwals and Folmer (2009). For the annual increase in labour productivity, we follow the European Commission (2009) and Van der Horst et al. (2010) by imputing 1.7 per cent annually.

The best practice might be to impute a different real discount rate for each year between 1946 and 2007. However, this would require past data on short-term government papers, which are not directly available for a such long period, as well as an estimate of past risk premiums.
See Van der Horst et al. (2010).

A policy is considered sustainable if, after 200 years (the time horizon of our model), government debt remains constant as a share of GDP. All variables then show a more-or-less steady-state development.

This paper ignores the measures that were decided on after June 2010. These measures reduce the sustainability gap by 3'/2 percentage points to 1 per cent of GDP. Including these measures would, however, not change the intergenerational picture presented in Figure 5, as this only means that (part of) the sustainability measures are now fdled in.
